article.title: GW170817/GRB 170817A/AT2017gfo association: some implications for physics and astrophysics

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main finding illustrated in Figure 1 regarding GRB 170817A in comparison to other sGRBs?
choices: GRB 170817A follows the typical correlations seen in other sGRBs.
GRB 170817A is significantly brighter than other sGRBs.
GRB 170817A is the weakest sGRB detected so far, but its spectral peak energy is comparable to some other sGRBs.
GRB 170817A and GRB 980425 have entirely different luminosities and spectral peak energies.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 2 primarily illustrate in the context of GW170817/AT2017gfo?
choices: Comparison of different models for the acceleration of the Universe.
Constraints on the sub-luminal movement of gravitational waves from various observations.
The strength of gravitational potential in different galaxies.
The relationship between the speed of light and the speed of gravitational waves.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the key implication of the data points representing GW170817 in Figure 3?
choices: Neutron star mergers are unlikely sources of heavy r-process elements.
The observed data supports the notion that neutron star mergers are significant sites of r-process element production.
The ejected mass from GW170817 is significantly larger than previously thought.
The rate of neutron star mergers in the Milky Way is much higher than in the local Universe.
